title: Sunday Six
body:
Then he stood up and walked to Arya’s table, and despite all her courage, Arya shrank in her bench. He was so big and fully armed, his dagger and sword clanging on his hip when he walked. Surely he wouldn’t do anything to her? Arya’s gaze flitted around the room to seek for a quick getaway.

The Hound sat opposite her, lifted his arms on the table and stared at her, saying nothing. After a while, and in the light of his non-threatening behaviour, Arya’s courage returned.

reblog.comment:

The Hound sat opposite her, lifted his arms on the table and stared at her, saying nothing. After a while, and in the light of his non-threatening behaviour, Arya’s courage returned.

The Hound sat opposite her, lifted his arms on the table and stared at her, saying nothing. After a while, and in the light of his non-threatening behaviour, Arya’s courage returned.
trail.content:

The Hound sat opposite her, lifted his arms on the table and stared at her, saying nothing. After a while, and in the light of his non-threatening behaviour, Arya’s courage returned.

blog.name: rainhadaenerys
blog.title: Daenerys Targaryen is the love of my life

summary:
Daenerys, Arya and Sansa on Knighthood   "There
was no higher honor than to receive your knighthood from the Prince...
body:
Daenerys, Arya and Sansa on Knighthood


“There was no higher honor than to receive your knighthood from the Prince of Dragonstone.”

“Tell me, then—when he touched a man on the shoulder with his sword, what did he say? ‘Go forth and kill the weak’? Or 'Go forth and defend them’? At the Trident, those brave men Viserys spoke of who died beneath our dragon banners—did they give their lives because they believed in Rhaegar’s cause, or because they had been bought and paid for?” Dany turned to Mormont, crossed her arms, and waited for an answer. – Daenerys II ASOS

Hot Pie was being silly; it wouldn’t be ghosts at Harrenhal, it would be knights. Arya could reveal herself to Lady Whent, and the knights would escort her home and keep her safe. That was what knights did; they kept you safe, especially women. Maybe Lady Whent would even help the crying girl. – Arya IV ACOK

“Aren’t you afraid? The gods might send you down to some terrible hell for all the evil you’ve done.”

“What evil?” He laughed. “What gods?”

“The gods who made us all.”

“All?” he mocked. “Tell me, little bird, what kind of god makes a monster like the Imp, or a halfwit like Lady Tanda’s daughter? If there are gods, they made sheep so wolves could eat mutton, and they made the weak for the strong to play with.”

“True knights protect the weak.” – Sansa IV ACOK

tags: she's genuinely trying to undermine him when he is the only one who can *save the world*
and people think arya's not a team player???
summary: In S8, when Arya is supporting Jon unconditionally as he tries to save the entire world and Sandra is undermining him and trying...
body: In S8, when Arya is supporting Jon unconditionally as he tries to save the entire world and Sandra is undermining him and trying to take his crown IN THE MIDDLE OF THE APOCALYPSE, make sure to ask the stans which sister is the one who’s too “damaged” and “sociopathic” to be part of a functioning society.

Now that the holidays are officially over, I’m already looking forward to Spring, so here are:

Likes and reblogs are much appreciated! (especially since it’s not showing up in the tags 😒)

summary: Yo, I'm so scared game of thrones is gonna have a gratifying and complete ending. Like, no, I want this series to haunt me until...
body: Yo, I’m so scared game of thrones is gonna have a gratifying and complete ending. Like, no, I want this series to haunt me until I die. We beyond this stage of everything falling together perfectly.

title: Arya & The Waif (S607-08)
body:
OK, so this is obviously a few years down the road, but I remain as confused as ever by the overwhelming complaints about Arya’s attack by and escape from the Waif. As I’ve mentioned, I’m rewatching the series. I just finished watching S0608, “No One,” and I kept looking for the implausibilities that everyone goes off about it and I just didn’t find them. So I’m gonna break this down.

In S0607 -

- The Waif came up from behind and slashed Arya across her stomach. Note, Arya was wearing a jerkin (a thick material) over another shirt. So that was two items of clothing that the Waif had to slice through in a quick motion with a smallish knife. In other words, that was not a deep cut.

- Then the Waif delivered one quick jab to Arya’s abdomen, enough to leave a puncture, yes, but she didn’t do it in a fatal area. Then she delivered another stab into Arya’s right side, this one she held the knife and twisted before pulling out. That was the worst of the wounds delivered.

- Arya pulled away and jumped into the water–and hey, it was likely a cooler season considering everyone was wearing long sleeves, pants, etc. even in a warmer climate, thus meaning it was likely cooler water. She popped up next, wet and shivering, and her wounds had been cleansed with (a) possibly cool water, and (b) most likely salt water at that.

- Next we saw her hiding in the actor’s backstage area. Lady Crane took her to her lodgings, further cleaned and then stitched her wounds, fed her and then gave her seed of the poppy to heal and sleep.

In S0608 -

- Arya woke up, having slept, rested and healed up some. She was a bit sore obviously, but after taking a few steps, she walked and stood normally, not holding her abdomen.

- The Waif had killed Lady Crane, and was coming after Arya… so adrenaline kicked in. Adrenaline is an incredible force. Mothers can literally lift a car to save their children because of adrenaline. Adrenaline can power people through illnesses, injuries, fear, etc., past all unbelievable endurance when their life or the lives of those they love is on the line. Arya’s life was literally on the line, plus, she’s been training non-stop for months and knows the streets like the back of her hands right now. Take all of that into account and follow all along with what came next.

- Arya jumped out of a one-story window. No biggie for someone (a) on a high-adrenaline rush, (b) has been hard-core training, © used to pain on the regular at this point.  She ran a bit, again, that adrenaline fueling and disguising any pain she might be feeling from the pull of her wounds.

- She slid under the cart, rolling against the street. Would it stretch against the stitching. It might, but they made a point of how good Lady Crane was at stitching of wounds and Arya was under that cart for less than 30 seconds. Plus, if it did pull at the stitching a bit, it wouldn’t have done so enough to start bleeding through yet. Anyway, after that, she was just running (again, the fuel of adrenaline, life on the line here, and training, used to the pain) and walking.

- Then Arya took that big leap, landing on the streets in a crash, rolling, rolling down that marketplace all along. How could nothing happen then? Well…. something did. She lay there for a good 5-10 seconds, breathing heavily, holding her wounds, and she started bleeding again. The stitches had come undone. She did manage to pull herself up, but she wasn’t able to run anymore. She could barely stand up. Her shirt was stained with blood where the wounds were. Even adrenaline couldn’t sustain her fully any longer.

It wasn’t until she got to her safe space, Needle, her candle, where she knew she had a chance to take on the Waif that she was able to once more find that final reserve of strength.

So somewhere tell me where there was anything more implausible in this than any other action sequence than has been normally accepted on this show… I don’t know; I think the Braavos arc was just such a disappointment overall for book readers (I feel that personally, I totally do) that it became fairly easy to nitpick everything about it as it got closer to the end.

- Then Arya took that big leap, landing on the streets in a crash, rolling, rolling down that marketplace all along. How could nothing happen then? Well…. something did. She lay there for a good 5-10 seconds, breathing heavily, holding her wounds, and she started bleeding again. The stitches had come undone. She did manage to pull herself up, but she wasn’t able to run anymore. She could barely stand up. Her shirt was stained with blood where the wounds were. Even adrenaline couldn’t sustain her fully any longer.

It wasn’t until she got to her safe space, Needle, her candle, where she knew she had a chance to take on the Waif that she was able to once more find that final reserve of strength.

So somewhere tell me where there was anything more implausible in this than any other action sequence than has been normally accepted on this show… I don’t know; I think the Braavos arc was just such a disappointment overall for book readers (I feel that personally, I totally do) that it became fairly easy to nitpick everything about it as it got closer to the end.
trail.content:
OK, so this is obviously a few years down the road, but I remain as confused as ever by the overwhelming complaints about Arya’s attack by and escape from the Waif. As I’ve mentioned, I’m rewatching the series. I just finished watching S0608, “No One,” and I kept looking for the implausibilities that everyone goes off about it and I just didn’t find them. So I’m gonna break this down.

In S0607 -

- The Waif came up from behind and slashed Arya across her stomach. Note, Arya was wearing a jerkin (a thick material) over another shirt. So that was two items of clothing that the Waif had to slice through in a quick motion with a smallish knife. In other words, that was not a deep cut.

- Then the Waif delivered one quick jab to Arya’s abdomen, enough to leave a puncture, yes, but she didn’t do it in a fatal area. Then she delivered another stab into Arya’s right side, this one she held the knife and twisted before pulling out. That was the worst of the wounds delivered.

- Arya pulled away and jumped into the water–and hey, it was likely a cooler season considering everyone was wearing long sleeves, pants, etc. even in a warmer climate, thus meaning it was likely cooler water. She popped up next, wet and shivering, and her wounds had been cleansed with (a) possibly cool water, and (b) most likely salt water at that.

- Next we saw her hiding in the actor’s backstage area. Lady Crane took her to her lodgings, further cleaned and then stitched her wounds, fed her and then gave her seed of the poppy to heal and sleep.

In S0608 -

- Arya woke up, having slept, rested and healed up some. She was a bit sore obviously, but after taking a few steps, she walked and stood normally, not holding her abdomen.

- The Waif had killed Lady Crane, and was coming after Arya… so adrenaline kicked in. Adrenaline is an incredible force. Mothers can literally lift a car to save their children because of adrenaline. Adrenaline can power people through illnesses, injuries, fear, etc., past all unbelievable endurance when their life or the lives of those they love is on the line. Arya’s life was literally on the line, plus, she’s been training non-stop for months and knows the streets like the back of her hands right now. Take all of that into account and follow all along with what came next.

- Arya jumped out of a one-story window. No biggie for someone (a) on a high-adrenaline rush, (b) has been hard-core training, © used to pain on the regular at this point.  She ran a bit, again, that adrenaline fueling and disguising any pain she might be feeling from the pull of her wounds.

- She slid under the cart, rolling against the street. Would it stretch against the stitching. It might, but they made a point of how good Lady Crane was at stitching of wounds and Arya was under that cart for less than 30 seconds. Plus, if it did pull at the stitching a bit, it wouldn’t have done so enough to start bleeding through yet. Anyway, after that, she was just running (again, the fuel of adrenaline, life on the line here, and training, used to the pain) and walking.

- Then Arya took that big leap, landing on the streets in a crash, rolling, rolling down that marketplace all along. How could nothing happen then? Well…. something did. She lay there for a good 5-10 seconds, breathing heavily, holding her wounds, and she started bleeding again. The stitches had come undone. She did manage to pull herself up, but she wasn’t able to run anymore. She could barely stand up. Her shirt was stained with blood where the wounds were. Even adrenaline couldn’t sustain her fully any longer.

It wasn’t until she got to her safe space, Needle, her candle, where she knew she had a chance to take on the Waif that she was able to once more find that final reserve of strength.

So somewhere tell me where there was anything more implausible in this than any other action sequence than has been normally accepted on this show… I don’t know; I think the Braavos arc was just such a disappointment overall for book readers (I feel that personally, I totally do) that it became fairly easy to nitpick everything about it as it got closer to the end.

summary: I'm not saying she will, but Arya saying "I'm going to kill the Queen" instead of "I'm going to kill Cersei Lannister" is...
